awd_titl_txt: Quantifying plant-soil feedback effects in classic diversity-productivity experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
A large of body of research suggests that two-way interactions between plants and soils, known as plant-soil feedbacks, have major effects on the abundance and distribution of plant species, and that soil bacteria and fungi are largely responsible. This project will provide a large-scale test of these important hypotheses. Plant-soil feedbacks will be measured in a large set of plant species at sites with ongoing, long-term experiments on plant diversity and productivity. The combined data will be used to construct models that relate feedbacks to productivity. Linked genetic studies will help identify the specific microbes that drive feedbacks. 

The broader impacts of the project include extensive training of students and outreach to K-12 education, and clear applications to agriculture. The project plans to train many undergraduate students, two Ph.D. students, and numerous high school students. The research has relevance to food production and food security because it is expected to identify key beneficial and harmful microbes and thus improve our understanding of how soil microbes can be used to manage crop growth.

por.por_cntn:
In the past ten years there has been a growing understanding of the pervasive effects that microorganisms have on larger organisms. These effects can be negative (i.e., disease) or positive (e.g., digestion). In humans, there is a growing interest in how our gut microbiome affects human health. A similar line of research has been developing to understand how soil organisms affect plant growth. This ‘plant-soil feedback’ research has revealed that plants cultivate soil microbial communities that can either increase or decrease subsequent plant growth. These interactions therefore, may play an important role in determining plant growth, coexistence and productivity. There are several important implications of these effects. For example, plant-soil feedbacks may be important in determining agricultural productivity, plant diversity, plant productivity in diverse communities and plant species invasions. Consequently, it is likely that a better understanding of these interactions will lead to the development of new management techniques that could increase agricultural production, the conservation of plant species and management of invasive plants.

While promising, the vast majority of plant-soil feedback research has simply measured the presence or absence of plant-soil feedbacks in short-term greenhouse experiments. As a result, three critical components of plant-soil feedbacks remain poorly understood: 1) are plant-soil feedbacks important in field conditions, 2) do plant-soil feedbacks help predict species coexistence and productivity in field conditions, and 3) which soil organisms cause these effects. In this research we addressed these questions.

We performed what we believe to be the two largest plant-soil feedback field experiments ever performed. These experiments included over 4,000 experimental plots in the field and another 4,000 experimental pots in paired greenhouse experiments. These comprehensive experiments provided the most detailed plant-soil feedback information available.  One important finding from these experiments is that greenhouse experiments provided qualitatively different results than field experiments. This is important because the vast majority of plant-soil feedback research to date has been performed in greenhouse experiments. The second major finding of this research is that plant-soil feedbacks were larger and provided better predictions of species coexistence and productivity in the drier grassland site in Minnesota than in the wetter site in Germany. The third major finding from our initial analyses is that plant-soil feedbacks appear to explain only 10 to 30 % of the increase in plant productivity observed in highly diverse relative to monoculture plant communities. Thus, plant-soil feedbacks appear to be a significant, but not overwhelming, determining of plant productivities in communities. Finally, this research has led to the creation of a new experimental design that can be used to identify novel plant growth promoting and plant growth inhibiting soil organisms. This is important because this new approach can be expected to help identify soil organisms that can, for example, increase agricultural food production or decrease invasive plant growth.

This project provided professional training and experience for 48 people in addition to the two principle investigators. Two PhD students (both female, one minority) were fully supported by this research. Two master’s student worked on this project. Forty-four undergraduate and post-baccalaureate students worked on our field and greenhouse research in Utah, Minnesota and Germany. Six of these students performed independent research projects associated with our research. Outreach from this research included eight publications targeted to the international scientific community (under review, in press or published), an additional eight publications in preparation by the PhD students supported by the project, ten presentations at local, national and international meetings. Support from this project provided one-week field ecology research experiences for six native American students. Hundreds of visitors to the Cedar Creek research site were introduced to our field experiment and basic plant-soil feedback concepts.

This research was designed so that field work was performed throughout the four-year funding period. As a result, much of the data from this research is currently being analyzed. Most of the results and anticipated outputs are forthcoming and expected to be produced in 2019 and 2020.
